title: Biden calls out  ferocious surge  of antisemitism
message:
"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world," Biden said as he delivered the keynote address at the U.S.
"We've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world," since the October attack, said Biden.
"We're grateful for President Biden's clear moral leadership confronting this threat, including through the historic U.S. National Strategy to Counter Antisemitism.
And antisemitism is hate speech.
It is just hate speech.

title: Biden decries surge of antisemitism since the October 7 Hamas attacks on Israel
message:
Biden drew a line from the atrocities in the Holocaust to the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks in Israel, and said what has followed that day has been despicable.
"We've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world," Biden said.
Biden last week delivered brief remarks denouncing "chaos" on college campuses, saying that things had gone too far.
"But there is no place on any campus in America — any place in America — for antisemitism or hate speech, or threats of violence or any kind," he said.
Saul Loeb / AFP via Getty Images / AFP via Getty Images President Biden and House Speaker Mike Johnson hold images of Holocaust victims during the annual Days of Remembrance ceremony at the U.S. Capitol.
event_breakdown:
- Biden's remarks connecting the Holocaust to Hamas attacks in Israel
- Surge of antisemitism in America and around the world
- Biden denouncing "chaos" on college campuses and condemning antisemitism and hate speech

title: Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests and Gaza war
message:
Biden has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas — the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust — with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.
While acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during "difficult times," Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of Palestinians in the war in Gaza.
Biden said, "There's no place on any campus in America" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence.
In conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond.
Biden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that "President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel — Donald Trump does not."
